id="ceip-home-carousel" data-ride="carousel" data-interval="15000" class="carousel carousel-full-screen slide ceip-home-carousel"><div id="normal" class="carousel-inner"><div id="global-pandemic-coronavirus-and-global-disorder" style="background-image: url(https://images.carnegieendowment.org/images/article_images/GettyImages-1206417619-homepage1.jpg);" class="item active regularly-updated-collection"><div class="slide-content"><div class="featureWrap"><div class="containerFeature"><h2><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/specialprojects/coronavirus">Global Pandemic: Coronavirus and Global Disorder</a></h2><div class="metaD"><div class="author"> <ul></ul></div><p class="pubType">regularly updated collection</p><p class="pubDate">Mon Mar 16 2020 20:00:00 GMT-0400 (EDT)</p></div><p><p>As the deadly coronavirus disrupts daily life around the world, Carnegie experts offer analysis on the political, economic, and geostrategic effects of the global pandemic.</p>
</p><div class="analytics-home-topics topics"></div></div></div></div></div><div id="the-united-states-and-the-new-world-disorder-retreat-from-primacy" data-slide-background="https://images.carnegieendowment.org/images/article_images/GettyImages-925618292-homepage.jpg" class="item commentary"><div class="slide-content"><div class="featureWrap"><div class="containerFeature"><h2><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/2020/05/21/united-states-and-new-world-disorder-retreat-from-primacy-pub-81876">The United States and the New World Disorder: Retreat From Primacy</a></h2><div class="metaD"><div class="author"> <ul><li><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/experts/1744">Aaron David Miller</a></li><li>, <a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/experts/1038">Richard Sokolsky</a></li></ul></div><p class="pubType">commentary</p><p class="pubDate">Wed May 20 2020 20:00:00 GMT-0400 (EDT)</p></div><p><p>The coronavirus pandemic has brought the era of highly ambitious U.S. diplomacy to an unceremonious end. As U.S. power wanes, is Washington ready for a world that has never needed it more and trusted it less?</p>
</p><div class="analytics-home-topics topics"><strong>Topics Discussed</strong><ul class="list-across"><li><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/regions/112">United States</a></li><li><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/topic/1296?lang=en">Foreign Policy</a></li></ul></div></div><div class="relatedFeatures"><ul><li><strong>On the Pandemic</strong><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/experts/1014">William J. Burns</a> explains how the coronavirus presents a <a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/2020/04/06/make-or-break-test-for-american-diplomacy-pub-81477">make-or-break moment for U.S. diplomacy</a></li>
<li><strong>On the United States</strong><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/experts/1014">William J. Burns</a> discusses the need for a <a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/2020/05/04/america-needs-rebirth-of-public-service-pub-81713">rebirth of U.S. public service</a></li>
</ul>
</div></div></div></div><div id="u-s-foreign-policy-for-the-middle-class-perspectives-from-nebraska" data-slide-background="https://images.carnegieendowment.org/images/article_images/iStock-459954433-homepage.jpg" class="item report"><div class="slide-content"><div class="featureWrap"><div class="containerFeature"><h2><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/2020/05/21/u.s.-foreign-policy-for-middle-class-perspectives-from-nebraska-pub-81767"> U.S. Foreign Policy for the Middle Class: Perspectives From Nebraska</a></h2><div class="metaD"><div class="author"> <ul><li><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/experts/1322"> Salman Ahmed</a></li><li>, Allison Gelman, eds.</li></ul></div><p class="pubType">report</p><p class="pubDate">Wed May 20 2020 20:00:00 GMT-0400 (EDT)</p></div><p><p>As millions of Americans contend with lost wages and savings due to the coronavirus, the challenge of making U.S. foreign policy work harder for the middle class is even more vital.</p>
</p><div class="analytics-home-topics topics"><strong>Topics Discussed</strong><ul class="list-across"><li><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/regions/112">United States</a></li><li><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/topic/1296">Foreign Policy</a></li></ul></div></div><div class="relatedFeatures"><ul><li><strong>On Colorado </strong>The task force looks at how U.S. foreign policy impacts <a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/2019/11/05/u.s.-foreign-policy-for-middle-class-perspectives-from-colorado-pub-80112">people in Colorado</a></li>
<li><strong>On Ohio </strong>The task force looks at how U.S. foreign policy impacts <a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/2018/12/10/u.s.-foreign-policy-for-middle-class-perspectives-from-ohio-pub-77779">people in Ohio</a></li>
</ul>
</div></div></div></div><div id="contentious-politics-in-the-syrian-conflict-opposition-representation-and-resistance" data-slide-background="https://images.carnegieendowment.org/images/article_images/GettyImages-147932591_homepage1.jpg" class="item compendium"><div class="slide-content"><div class="featureWrap"><div class="containerFeature"><h2><a href="https://carnegie-mec.org/2020/05/15/contentious-politics-in-syrian-conflict-opposition-representation-and-resistance-pub-81798">Contentious Politics in the Syrian Conflict: Opposition, Representation, and Resistance</a></h2><div class="metaD"><div class="author"> <ul><li><a href="https://carnegie-mec.org/experts/926">Maha Yahya</a></li></ul></div><p class="pubType">Compendium</p><p class="pubDate">Wed May 20 2020 20:00:00 GMT-0400 (EDT)</p></div><p><p>The Assad regime&rsquo;s instinct to survive at any cost closed off opportunities for change in Syria, yet contentious politics was possible and is still taking place.</p>
</p><div class="analytics-home-topics topics"><strong>Topics Discussed</strong><ul class="list-across"><li><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/regions/187">Syria</a></li><li><a href="https://carnegie-mec.org/topic/1417">Arab Politics</a></li></ul></div></div><div class="relatedFeatures"><ul><li><strong>On Syria</strong>Experts discuss <a href="https://carnegie-mec.org/diwan/81766">the reason behind the leadership tensions inside Syria</a> | <a href="https://carnegie-mec.org/diwan/81797">عربي</a></li>
<li><strong>On the Syrian Military</strong>Muhsen Al Mustafa explains how <a href="https://carnegie-mec.org/diwan/81781">Syria&rsquo;s military has been affected by sectarianism</a> | <a href="https://carnegie-mec.org/diwan/81813">عربي</a></li>
</ul>
</div></div></div></div><div id="could-the-pandemic-jump-start-national-reconciliation-in-palestine" data-slide-background="https://images.carnegieendowment.org/images/article_images/GettyImages-1207338230-homepage.jpg" class="item article"><div class="slide-content"><div class="featureWrap"><div class="containerFeature"><h2><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/2020/05/20/could-pandemic-jump-start-national-reconciliation-in-palestine-pub-81833">Could the Pandemic Jump-Start National Reconciliation in Palestine?</a></h2><div class="metaD"><div class="author"> <ul><li><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/experts/1654">Zaha Hassan</a></li><li>, <a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/experts/238">Nathan J. Brown</a></li></ul></div><p class="pubType">article</p><p class="pubDate">Wed May 20 2020 20:00:00 GMT-0400 (EDT)</p></div><p><p>Palestinian grassroots organizations are leading the response to the coronavirus pandemic. Many factors will weigh on this new activism&rsquo;s longevity.</p>
</p><div class="analytics-home-topics topics"><strong>Topics Discussed</strong><ul class="list-across"><li><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/regions/183">Palestine</a></li><li><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/specialprojects/coronavirus">Global Pandemic</a></li></ul></div></div><div class="relatedFeatures"><ul><li><strong>On Palestine </strong><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/experts/1654">Zaha Hassan</a> and Hallaamal Keir write that it is up to Israel to <a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/2020/03/30/it-s-up-to-israel-to-stop-coronavirus-catastrophe-among-palestinians-pub-81421">stop a coronavirus catastrophe among Palestinians</a></li>
<li><strong>On U.S. Policy </strong><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/experts/1654">Zaha Hassan</a> and Hallaamal Keir examine <a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/2020/03/30/u.s.-policy-response-to-coronavirus-in-gaza-pub-81390">U.S. policy responses to the coronavirus in Gaza</a></li>
</ul>
</div></div></div></div><div id="south-asia-s-battle-with-the-coronavirus" data-slide-background="https://images.carnegieendowment.org/images/article_images/GettyImages-1211027197-homepage.jpg" class="item compendium"><div class="slide-content"><div class="featureWrap"><div class="containerFeature"><h2><a href="https://carnegieindia.org/2020/05/21/south-asia-s-battle-with-coronavirus-pub-81850">South Asia’s Battle With the Coronavirus</a></h2><div class="metaD"><div class="author"> <ul><li>Rhea Menon</li><li>, <a href="https://carnegieindia.org/experts/1666">Srinath Raghavan</a></li></ul></div><p class="pubType">compendium</p><p class="pubDate">Wed May 20 2020 20:00:00 GMT-0400 (EDT)</p></div><p><p>In South Asia, the coronavirus pandemic is at once a public health crisis, an economic crisis, and a humanitarian crisis.</p>
</p><div class="analytics-home-topics topics"><strong>Topics Discussed</strong><ul class="list-across"><li><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/regions/231">India</a></li><li><a href="https://carnegieindia.org/specialprojects/coronaviruspandemic">Coronavirus Pandemic in India</a></li></ul></div></div><div class="relatedFeatures"><ul><li><strong>Webinar </strong>Experts discuss the <a href="https://carnegieindia.org/2020/05/15/coronavirus-and-future-of-indian-foreign-policy-event-7327">coronavirus and the future of Indian foreign policy</a></li>
<li><strong>On India </strong>Gautam I. Menon examines <a href="https://carnegieindia.org/2020/05/14/india-s-unheeded-coronavirus-warning-pub-81805">India&rsquo;s unheeded coronavirus warning</a></li>
</ul>
</div></div></div></div><div id="global-protest-tracker" data-slide-background="https://images.carnegieendowment.org/images/article_images/GettyImages-1139583950-homepage.jpg" class="item interactive"><div class="slide-content"><div class="featureWrap"><div class="containerFeature"><h2><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/publications/interactive/protest-tracker">Global Protest Tracker</a></h2><div class="metaD"><div class="author"> <ul></ul></div><p class="pubType">interactive</p><p class="pubDate">Tue Mar 31 2020 20:00:00 GMT-0400 (EDT)</p></div><p><p>A one-stop source for following crucial trends in the most significant antigovernment protests worldwide since 2017.</p>
</p><div class="analytics-home-topics topics"><strong>Topics Discussed</strong><ul class="list-across"><li><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/programs/democracy/">Democracy, Conflict, and Governance</a></li><li><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/topic/1301">Civil Society</a></li></ul></div></div></div></div></div><div id="america-needs-a-rebirth-of-public-service" data-slide-background="https://images.carnegieendowment.org/images/article_images/GettyImages-1222310618-_1_.jpg" class="item atlantic"><div class="slide-content"><div class="featureWrap"><div class="containerFeature"><h2><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/2020/05/04/america-needs-rebirth-of-public-service-pub-81713">America Needs a Rebirth of Public Service</a></h2><div class="metaD"><div class="author"> <ul><li><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/experts/1014">William J. Burns</a></li></ul></div><p class="pubType"><em>Atlantic</em></p><p class="pubDate">Sun Feb 23 2020 19:00:00 GMT-0500 (EST)</p></div><p><p>If ever there were a moment to call Americans to serve, it&rsquo;s now. To help ensure they answer that call, it&rsquo;s time to end the war on government, revive U.S. institutions, and shape a new era of public service.</p>
</p><div class="analytics-home-topics topics"><strong>Topics Discussed</strong><ul class="list-across"><li><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/regions/108?lang=en">Americas</a></li><li><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/regions/112?lang=en">United States</a></li><li><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/topic/1296?lang=en">Foreign Policy</a></li><li><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/topic/1287?lang=en">Economy</a></li></ul></div></div><div class="relatedFeatures"><ul><li><strong>On the United States&nbsp;</strong><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/experts/145">George Perkovich</a>&nbsp;<a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/2020/05/06/critiquing-state-department-s-nuclear-posture-clarification-pub-81722">critiques the state department&rsquo;s nuclear posture clarification</a></li>
<li><strong>On Foreign Policy&nbsp;</strong><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/experts/1803">Dan Baer</a>&nbsp;explains why the <a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/2020/04/02/political-campaigns-must-go-on-and-they-still-need-you-even-during-pandemic-pub-81469">political campaigns must go on, even during a pandemic</a></li>
</ul>
</div></div></div></div><div id="can-the-coronavirus-heal-polarization" data-slide-background="https://images.carnegieendowment.org/images/article_images/GettyImages-1211035038_6a087f9f-0472-4866-9107-354cc8efe92e1.jpg" class="item article"><div class="slide-content"><div class="featureWrap"><div class="containerFeature"><h2><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/2020/05/01/can-coronavirus-heal-polarization-pub-81704">Can the Coronavirus Heal Polarization?</a></h2><div class="metaD"><div class="author"> <ul><li><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/experts/699">Rachel Kleinfeld</a></li><li>, <a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/experts/1748">Ashley Quarcoo</a></li></ul></div><p class="pubType">article</p><p class="pubDate">Thu Jan 30 2020 19:00:00 GMT-0500 (EST)</p></div><p><p>Polarization is straining democracies around the world, but effective governance and mobilization during the crisis could help narrow social divides.</p>
</p><div class="analytics-home-topics topics"><strong>Topics Discussed</strong><ul class="list-across"><li><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/topic/1286?lang=en">Democracy and Governance</a></li><li><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/topic/1298?lang=en">Political Reform</a></li></ul></div></div><div class="relatedFeatures"><ul><li><strong>On Democracy and Governance&nbsp;</strong><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/experts/1014">William J. Burns</a>&nbsp;explains why <a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/2020/05/04/america-needs-rebirth-of-public-service-pub-81713">America needs a rebirth of public service</a></li>
<li><strong>On Political Reform&nbsp;</strong><a href="https://carnegie-mec.org/diwan/experts/758">Marc Pierini</a>&nbsp;looks into <a href="https://carnegie-mec.org/diwan/81717">Turkey&rsquo;s looming Gordian knot</a></li>
</ul>
</div></div></div></div><div id="is-it-a-nuke-pre-launch-ambiguity-and-inadvertent-escalation" data-slide-background="https://images.carnegieendowment.org/images/article_images/ActonWarheads_1420x7705.jpg" class="item "><div class="slide-content"><div class="featureWrap"><div class="containerFeature"><h2><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/2020/04/09/is-it-nuke-pre-launch-ambiguity-and-inadvertent-escalation-pub-81446">Is It a Nuke?: Pre-Launch Ambiguity and Inadvertent Escalation</a></h2><div class="metaD"><div class="author"> <ul><li><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/experts/434">James M. Acton</a></li></ul></div><p class="pubType"></p><p class="pubDate">Thu Jan 30 2020 19:00:00 GMT-0500 (EST)</p></div><p><p>It&rsquo;s becoming increasingly difficult to distinguish a nuclear weapon from a conventional one. The risk of misidentifying either&mdash;especially prior to its launch&mdash;is an underappreciated and growing danger. At a time of geopolitical uncertainty, this confusion could spark a nuclear war.</p>
</p><div class="analytics-home-topics topics"><strong>Topics Discussed</strong><ul class="list-across"><li><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/regions/108?lang=en">Americas</a></li><li><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/regions/303?lang=en">Russia</a></li><li><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/topic/1296?lang=en">Foreign Policy</a></li><li><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/experts/434">Nuclear Weapons</a></li></ul></div></div><div class="relatedFeatures"><ul><li><strong>On Nuclear Weapons&nbsp;</strong><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/experts/1265">Ulrich Kuhn</a>&nbsp;discusses <a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/2020/04/20/nuclear-risk-in-euro-atlantic-pub-81604">nuclear risk in the Euro-Atlantic</a></li>
<li><strong>On Foreign Policy </strong><a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/experts/1734">David Whineray</a> details how Trump&rsquo;s actions <a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/2020/04/17/trump-s-actions-allowed-china-to-gain-huge-global-influence.-but-coronavirus-has-gifted-him-opportunity-pub-81589">allowed China to gain huge global influence</a></li>
</ul>
</div></div></div></div></div><div class="carousel-nav alt-slider-nav"><ol class="clean-list carousel-indicators"><li data-target="#ceip-home-carousel" data-slide-to="0" class="active"></li><li data-target="#ceip-home-carousel" data-slide-to="1"></li><li data-target="#ceip-home-carousel" data-slide-to="2"></li><li data-target="#ceip-home-carousel" data-slide-to="3"></li><li data-target="#ceip-home-carousel" data-slide-to="4"></li><li data-target="#ceip-home-carousel" data-slide-to="5"></li><li data-target="#ceip-home-carousel" data-slide-to="6"></li><li data-target="#ceip-home-carousel" data-slide-to="7"></li><li data-target="#ceip-home-carousel" data-slide-to="8"></li><li data-target="#ceip-home-carousel" data-slide-to="9"></li></ol><a href="#ceip-home-carousel" role="button" data-slide="next" class="next-button slide-control"><div class="ceip-icon icon-triangle-right"></div></a><a href="#ceip-home-carousel" role="button" data-slide="prev" class="prev-button slide-control"><div class="ceip-icon icon-triangle-left"></div></a></div></div><script src="/js/homepage.min.js"></script><!-- facebook pixel for homepage tracking, elsewise it is line 44 in footer--><script>!function(f,b,e,v,n,t,s){if(f.fbq)return;n=f.fbq=function(){n.callMethod?
